articles.headline: Google Aims to Make YouTube Profitable With Ads
articles.snippet: Google believes it finally has found the formula to cash in on YouTube’s potential as a magnet for online video advertising and keep its audience loyal at the same time.
articles.abstract: Google believes it finally has found the formula to cash in on YouTube’s potential as a magnet for online video advertising and keep its audience loyal at the same time.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever since Google bought YouTube last November, it has avoided cluttering the site and the video clips themselves with ads, for fear of alienating its audience.

articles.headline: Developer’s Big Manhattan Move Faces a Time and Credit Squeeze
articles.snippet: There is much speculation in the commercial real estate market that Harry Macklowe, the New York developer, is in trouble.
articles.abstract: There is much speculation in the commercial real estate market that Harry Macklowe, the New York developer, is in trouble.
articles.lead_paragraph: Harry Macklowe, the New York developer, was flying high in February when he decided to buy a portfolio of prime Midtown Manhattan office towers for nearly $7 billion, using only $50 million of his own money.

articles.headline: Misgivings Spoil Plans of Start-Up
articles.snippet: An underwriter has pulled out of the initial public offering for Accoona, a new Internet search engine that former President Bill Clinton helped introduce.
articles.abstract: An underwriter has pulled out of the initial public offering for Accoona, a new Internet search engine that former President Bill Clinton helped introduce.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three years ago, at a news conference at Tavern on the Green restaurant that featured a free-flowing bar, former President Bill Clinton helped introduce a new Internet search engine, Accoona, which was said to be powered by innovative artificial intelligence technology.

articles.headline: Bid to Reopen Mine Divides Grieving Utah Town
articles.snippet: Officials said the mine where six workers were trapped could resume operating with a new name.
articles.abstract: Officials said the mine where six workers were trapped could resume operating with a new name.
articles.lead_paragraph: HUNTINGTON, Utah, Aug. 21 — As relatives on Tuesday laid to rest one of three men killed here trying to rescue six trapped miners, this grieving mining town was torn over the future of the mine and the prospect of the lost miners’ being entombed permanently.
articles.byline: By Susan Saulny and Cara Buckley

articles.headline: Bush Takes a Step Away From Maliki
articles.snippet: The White House is trying to distance itself from the Iraqi prime minister before President Bush’s troop buildup is re-evaluated.
articles.abstract: The White House is trying to distance itself from the Iraqi prime minister before President Bush’s troop buildup is re-evaluated.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 — When President Bush and Nuri Kamal al-Maliki stood side by side in Jordan last November, the president proclaimed the prime minister “the right guy for Iraq.”
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Fed Seeks Balance as Investors Clamor for Action
articles.snippet: After another day of anxiety in the credit markets, Wall Street thinks the Federal Reserve is running short of time.
articles.abstract: After another day of anxiety in the credit markets, Wall Street thinks the Federal Reserve is running short of time.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 — Wall Street thinks the Federal Reserve is running short of time.

articles.headline: Atop Delta, a Veteran of Airlines
articles.snippet: Delta Air Lines named Richard H. Anderson, the former head of Northwest Airlines, as its new chief executive, passing over two Delta executives once considered the top candidates.
articles.abstract: Delta Air Lines named Richard H. Anderson, the former head of Northwest Airlines, as its new chief executive, passing over two Delta executives once considered the top candidates.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Aug. 21 — With Northwest Airlines’ former chief executive now in charge at Delta Air Lines, could closer ties between the companies be far behind?
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Pushing Fed to Act Early if Not Often
articles.snippet: In the future, the Federal Reserve Bank should push harder against a bubble while it is still inflating.
articles.abstract: In the future, the Federal Reserve Bank should push harder against a bubble while it is still inflating.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ben Bernanke got his first chance to use the chairmanship of the Federal Reserve to influence the housing market before he even officially had the job. It came in November 2005, toward the end of his all-day Senate confirmation hearing, when Senator Paul Sarbanes brought up the mortgage business.
